title: Stargate.io Demo on DataStax Astra DB using Postman | David Joy
description:
#ExpertAdvice #Stargate
David Joy gives a quick introduction on how Stargate API gateway works using Postman and DataStax Astra.

Sample code https://github.com/david-joy-ds/Stargate-Postman
Docs https://stargate.io/
Repository https://github.com/stargate/stargate

LEARN FOR FREE at https://www.datastax.com/dev -- access all the FREE complete courses, tutorials, and hands-on exercises.
BUILD APPS with https://astra.datastax.com/sample-app-gallery -- get started with one of the sample apps.
ASK QUESTIONS at https://community.datastax.com -- where experts from DataStax & the Apache Cassandra community share their expertise everyday.
SUBSCRIBE to https://www.youtube.com/DataStaxDevs -- get notified of new tutorials and hands-on live workshops every week.

transcript.text: hello everyone my name is david joy and i'm here to talk to you about stargate what we're going to do here is a quick demo of stargate with astra using postman so stargate is an api framework or sort of like a gateway that we have recently released from datastax and what it allows you to do is have various apis framework and programming language sit in one space that allows you to connect to your cassandra uh products so it can be data stacks enterprise it can be open source cassandra or the managed services of offering that is astra what i have here is a couple of options uh i have an authentication api i have apis for rest for making rest calls uh i have document api and document apis is something that typically is not something that we have heard about or used typically with cassandra but document apis are something that now you would be able to use with uh stargate and uh with with cassandra we also have graphql apis available through stargate that we will be using to connect to astra and cassandra so in today's demo i'm going to show you how these apis really work and we will not go too deep into it there's plenty of documentation available to see how it works a couple of things that i want to talk to you about here is that what i have is i have automated a few things so for example if in postman i've created an environment for stargate and if you can see i have updated my database information here and this database information is basically your astra cluster id uh astra's region information my username and password for that database and the key space to which i am writing or creating tables or i'm writing data and we have token information which is basically the authentication token and table information and some other information for for variables so let's start off by looking at authentication api so we have to do a post request to this endpoint and if you can notice here is i'm passing the variable db that comes from our stargate uh you know environment similarly the region is getting called so the variable is essentially calling it and what we are doing is we are hitting the rest v1 auth api and along with this what i've also done is i've written a small test script what it does is when whatever the response we are getting we are going to take that response and save it into this token file and update the token in the environment so that ways when you run the subsequent rest api calls or graphql or document apis you don't have to add or update the token information so what let's let's have a quick look at what happens so let's and it has sent an auth token this odd token has been read because of this script and has been updated in our environment so you see it's the same or token that is available here so let's go into rest api's create table uh endpoint and what you can notice is it's pretty much the same thing all the way till b1 and after that we have to mention key space which key space we want to create the table in and then the table information now we want to pass column information and column definition and what is the partition key all of that information so we are sending that as a json so make sure that you select a text make it raw and then change it to json and what you will also have to see is that i've already automated the x cassandra token information that needs to be sent along with the header and the token information is now automated because it's coming from the target environment that we have set so making some of the things easier so let's just create and in this particular case cannot add already exists the main reason why this error really came was because we already have the table so for the purposes of the demo what i've done is i've dropped the table and i'm going to send the request again through the rest apis create table endpoint so let's do that and when you try to do it for the first time because you're creating a table it takes a bit longer maybe three seconds if you can see here and we have created this table and now let's go into the insert data into the table endpoint and now we're here and what you can notice here is what we have to do is you're passing an instance statement in through the body uh so let's do this let's create id one let's do joe harvill h31 and we are creating a small collection here in the form of a map and all of that we are sending so same thing all the way to tables and after that you have to mention the table name that is also updated from our environment and then sending uh calling the rows uh endpoint so overall let's just send it this data has been created successfully added let's do one more thing let's add another user ie3 all right so we have added three records now into um the the database through the insert endpoint now let's retrieve that so again the difference between this request and this request is pretty much the same except for the fact that you're going to do a get request instead of post everything else is the same except for the fact that after the rose url you have to add the primary key so i'm setting the prime to key um last it was one so if you can come here we notice is that we have all the information that we loaded for joe it's getting retrieved coming back as a json which is amazing because that's how i wanted again i'm searching for a primary key with two primary key with three and the data is getting updated so so it's super easy now with this rest endpoints you can also search and query by creating a filter query or a submit query and that you can actually pass as the whole query as a json file so if you see here what i want is i want just the id the first name and the last name and age and i'm searching for id equals to one which is my partition key and the operator is equal to and i'm sending it with the url in the same url except for the fact that instead of sending the primary key or the partition key i'm sending actually the query uh as a as a part of the body and again if you see the header the token is getting uh updated that information is already there so if you send this what you see is only those specific columns have been read and we have the information the way we want it now let's go and update a record so let's let's go and update maybe uh for row number two let's change my name to like somebody else right and and let's just do this and as soon as you do this you see that information has been updated we can go back and do a get request with this and you see that person's name has been changed my name is was david and now it's been changed so different urls different endpoints available with rest apis and it's made things so much more easier so now as you were saying the key thing here to remember when you're updating it that the request that you have is basically a put request and not a post or a get so make sure you do that again everything else is pretty much the same and now let's delete the record so let's look at drop the third row in our astra table and let's just send the partition key again the difference is it's basically the put request the same end point except for the fact that the request that you're sending is a is a delete instead of a put so and we're sending row three and again and that has completed if you can now go and try to retrieve third record that record has gone i mean just to verify you know let's add don's information again and now if we go back and search for it that data is available so all these endpoints actually make life so much more easier for developers to interact with the database uh and in our case astra is managed by cassandra so you can focus on developing with these endpoints so this is rest apis and rest api is a very popular and a technique that many developers are using but let's go to the next layer that is document apis now document api is basically comes in the state where you have a json uh and a payload these these payloads have 10 documents sub documents or 20 sub documents and they can keep changing and you don't want to go and deal with you know changing your schema or your table definition all the time and you don't want to focus on dealing with the overhead of the requirements of the database but you just want to deal with uh have a document drop it retrieve it that kind of a scenario so typically which document api is what we are seeing is you have a json all right so here i have a game document which is basically a json of game and that is there's information about uh that game you know current state some audience size different round uh basically different sub documents available for that game and it's in the form of a json and i just want to load this and not deal with creating uh
